Wish You Were Here: Vacation tips from fellow travelers Bay Area News Group readers Posted: 07/22/2015 03:00:00 PM PDT Updated: 07/31/2015 08:00:01 AM PDT FRANCE: Clara and Rich DiBona, of Hayward, are just back from visiting Rouen, Bayeux and the D-Day beaches. Seeing the abbey on Mont Saint-Michel day or night was especially awe inspiring, despite the wall-to-wall people, Rich says. (DiBona Family) Courtesy of the DiBona Family FRANCE: Clara and Rich DiBona, of Hayward, are just back from visiting Rouen, Bayeux and the D-Day beaches. "Seeing the abbey on Mont Saint-Michel day or night was especially awe inspiring, despite the wall-to-wall people," Rich says. "Touring the expansive Omaha and Utah beaches needs at least a full day -- at a minimum -- to appreciate. Don't miss the chance to see the Bayeux Tapestry if you're in the area." 
Travel tips: "Renting a car allows you to maximize your time to enjoy what there is to see. Having a smartphone to access Google maps is very useful." Courtesy of the Ross Family SOUTH AFRICA: The Ross family is just back from South Africa, where Sunnyvale resident Aaron Ross, left; Annapolis, Maryland, resident Carl Smit; and Santa Cruz s Mike Holt attending the opening ceremony of the 2015 5O5 World Championship Regatta in Port Elizabeth. (Ross Family) SOUTH AFRICA: The Ross family is just back from South Africa, where Sunnyvale resident Aaron Ross, left; Annapolis, Maryland, resident Carl Smit; and Santa Cruz's Mike Holt attended the opening ceremony of the 2015 5O5 World Championship Regatta in Port Elizabeth. "The 5O5 is a 5.05 meter high performance, two-person racing dinghy, which has a large world wide fleet," Aaron's mother, Diana, says. "Carl and Mike won the championship. Mike was also the 2014 champion. This was the fleet's 60th anniversary. The children holding the flag are junior sailors from the Algoa Bay Yacht Club in Port Elizabeth." 
After the regatta, the Rosses spent a week on a photo safari in the Eastern Cape and Kruger National Park. Advertisement 
Travel tips: "South Africa is a beautiful country and very easy to navigate. The official language is English. The residents are very helpful and usually speak a minimum of three languages. The U.S. dollar to the SAR (rand) is very strong." Share your travels with us! Send your recent vacation selfies to jburrell@bayareanewsgroup.com . Be sure to tell us who's who, where they're from and where you are -- and include a couple of travel tips to help fellow readers globe-trot too.
